Award.AwardTitle: Spatial Analysis of Historical Fire Regimes and Landscape Structure in Sagebrush Ecosystems of the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Reconstructing evidence of historical fires is difficult at the large spatial extent required to understand whether recent large wildfires like the 652,358 acre Murphy Complex fires of 2007 in Idaho and Nevada sagebrush, are unprecedented or also occurred historically, prior to widespread EuroAmerican land uses. This limitation is particularly problematic in sagebrush ecosystems, which cover about 47 million ha of the western United States, as tree-ring evidence of historical fires is limited to forests and woodlands on the margin of these ecosystems. As a consequence, little is known about the structure of historical sagebrush landscapes or the rates and patterns of historical wildfires in these landscapes.

Professor William Baker at the University of Wyoming will reconstruct historical fire regimes and landscape structure in sagebrush ecosystems in the United States using the General Land Office Surveys of the late 1800s. Surveyors recorded the location of wildfires and early-successional postfire vegetation as they laid out section lines. Section-line information can be computerized and converted into maps of historical vegetation to allow spatial analysis of historical fires and landscape structure. The study will acquire, process, and analyze survey records for sample sagebrush landscapes of about 2,223,900 acres in each of four major floristic provinces spanning the range of sagebrush in the United States, and use these records to reconstruct historical fires and landscape structure. The research will address nine specific hypotheses about historical fire regimes and landscape structure in sagebrush. These hypotheses center on (1) historical fire-size distributions, (2) the patchiness of historical fires, (3) the frequency at which fire historically burned across landscapes, (4) the structure and size of historical landscapes, and (5) geographical variation in historical fire regimes and landscape structure.

Sagebrush is the sole habitat for a host of sagebrush-obligate species, some that are declining or are already listed as threatened or endangered, for example Sage Grouse. Sagebrush is also key forage for major populations of native ungulates, such as deer and elk, on their winter ranges. This study will substantially enhance basic understanding of spatial variation in a key natural wildfire disturbance and its historical influence on the structure of large landscapes representing a major western ecosystem. Improved information on historical wildfires will help understand if there is a wildfire contribution to declining species and how to manage wildfires and sagebrush on key winter ranges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sagebrush ecosystems in the United States appear to be burning in large fires, which raises several questions. For example, are these fires natural or a consequence of flammable invasive plants, such as cheatgrass, or possibly climatic change? Sagebrush dominates > 100 million acres and provides habitat for hundreds of species, including sage-grouse and other species under consideration for listing under the U.S. Endangered Species Act. However, little is known about historical fires in sagebrush or the nature of sagebrush landscapes prior to the expansion of EuroAmerican land uses in the late-1800s. There also has been no analysis of whether there are trends in fire in recent decades across the range of sagebrush.

To begin to address these questions we used General Land Office surveys conducted in the late-1800s to reconstruct patterns and rates of burning as well as the characteristics of sagebrush landscapes near or before the time of EuroAmerican land-use expansion. Surveyors recorded information about sagebrush vegetation as surveyors walked along 1-mile section lines. We compiled this information for about 39,000 surveryor observations across about 28,000 miles of surveying in five study areas totalling about 6 million acres in southeastern Oregon, eastern Idaho, southwestern Wyoming, northeastern Nevada, and western Colorado. These data show that sagebrush landscapes in the mid- to late-1800s were dominated by large, contiguous areas of sagebrush, interrrupted by some large grass-dominated areas representing fires and finer mosaics of grass and sagebrush also from fires. Sagebrush was not uniform in density or cover, but was instead described as dense across 20-25% of the study area, scattered across 15-16% and the remainder was not described. Most surprising was that an added area, equal to between 4-24% of the sagebrush area, was described by surveyors as sagebrush with trees, in which the trees were the lesser component. This was unexpected, as earlier research suggested that historical sagebrush landscapes generally lacked trees. Many restoration programs have sought to remove these trees, thinking they were unnatural encroachment because of fire suppression, livestock grazing or other land-use effects.

Regarding historical fires, we were able to reconstruct > 550 fire patches and > 270 fires from the survey records. Fire patches varied in size over a large range, with many more small than large patches. The largest sagebrush fires were about 312,000 acres in southeastern Oregon, 118,000 acres in Idaho, 79,000 acres in Nevada, 29,000 acres in Colorado, and 24,000 acres in Wyoming, but the average fire was only about 500-600 acres. Fires did not recur often, requiring between about 100-350 years to burn once across sagebrush landscapes.These periods were long, providing ample time for sagebrush to recover and reach maturity after fires and dominate large contiguous expanses as documented by the surveys. Also, these periods were sufficiently long to allow trees to disperse into and increase in sagebrush landscapes, as was also documented.

To study modern trends in sagebrush fires and compare them to the historical reconstructions, we analyzed 25 years (1984-2008) of government records of larger sagebrush fires (generally larger than 1000 acres) across most of the sagebrush range (about 117 million acres) in the United States. No upward trend in annual area burned was found across the whole area, consistent with previous computer models that suggested fire may not increase in semiarid shrublands. At a finer scale, upward trends were found in higher-elevation sagebrush and in two floristic provinces. Area burned was concentrated in years with large fires.
